prompt:
Can I customize the user profile fields that are populated from the OpenID Connect provider in XWiki?
I want to map additional user profile fields from my OpenID Connect provider to XWiki user properties. How can I achieve this?
expected_answer:
Yes, you can customize the user profile fields that are populated from the OpenID Connect provider by mapping them in the `xwiki.properties` file.

To map additional user profile fields, use the `oidc.user.mapping` property. Here's an example of how to map custom properties:

```
# oidc.user.mapping=myxproperty1=${oidc.user.subject}
# oidc.user.mapping=myxproperty2=myprefix-${oidc.user.subject}
```

Replace `myxproperty1` and `myxproperty2` with the actual XWiki user property names, and `${oidc.user.subject}` with the appropriate variable based on the data provided by your OpenID Connect provider.

After configuring the mappings, save the `xwiki.properties` file and restart XWiki to apply the changes.

Sources: https://extensions.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Extension/OpenID%20Connect/OpenID%20Connect%20Authenticator/ 


Yes, you can customize and extend the functionality of your XWiki instance by mapping additional user profile fields from an OpenID Connect (OIDC) provider to specific XWiki user properties using a combination of OIDC configuration settings in `xwiki.properties` file along with some Java code modifications if necessary. Here's how you can achieve this:

1. Configure the OIDC Provider Settings: 
   - Open or create an XML file named "oidc-provider" under your XWiki installation directory (e.g., `xwiki/conf/oidc-provider`). This is where we will define our custom mappings and properties for each provider type supported by the OIDC plugin in XWiki, which includes Google, Facebook, GitHub, etc.
   - Add a new entry to this XML file with your OpenID Connect Provider details (e.g., `providerId`, `clientId`, `redirectUri`). You can find these values on the developer console of your chosen provider or in their documentation if available. 
   
2. Define Custom Mappings: In the same "oidc-provider" XML file, add a new entry for each additional user profile field you want to map from your OpenID Connect Provider (e.g., `firstName`, `lastName`). Here's an example of how this can be done using Google as our OIDC provider:
```xml
<oidc-provider id="google" clientId="${client_id}" redirectUri="${redirect_uri}">
    <property name="user.name" value="@account_email@gmail.com"/> <!-- Default user property -->
    <mapping>
        <from field="givenName"/> <!-- Google's first name profile field -->
        <to xwiki:type="xwiki/UserPropertyValue">firstName</to>
    </mapping>
    <mapping>
        <from field="familyName"/> <!-- Google's last name profile field -->
        <to xwiki:type="xwiki/UserPropertyValue">lastName</to>
    </mapping>
</oidc-provider>
```
In this example, we are mapping the `givenName` and `familyName` fields from Google to XWiki user properties named "firstName" and "lastName", respectively. You can add as many mappings as you need for your specific use case by following a similar structure in XML format within each provider entry under `<oidc-provider>`.
   
3. Update `xwiki.properties` File: In the XWiki installation directory, locate and open or create an empty file named "xwiki.properties". Add custom properties for your additional user profile fields using this syntax (e.g., `"firstName"=""`): 
```properties
user.name=@account_email@gmail.com
firstName=""
lastName=""
```
In the above example, we have defined three XWiki-specific custom properties: `user.name`, `firstName`, and `lastName`. You can add as many of these custom user property definitions to your "xwiki.properties" file based on how many additional fields you want to map from your OpenID Connect provider.
   
4. Customize XWiki User Properties (if necessary): If the default properties provided by XWiki do not meet your requirements, or if they need further customization for handling special characters and formatting issues in user profile data coming from an OIDC Provider, you may have to modify some Java code within `xwiki-user.properties` file located under `/WEB-INF/classes`. This step is optional but recommended when dealing with complex or non-standardized user profiles that require additional processing before being stored as XWiki properties (e.g., converting special characters, trimming whitespace).
   
5. Test and Validate: After completing the above steps, restart your XWiki instance to apply these changes. Log in using an account from your OpenID Connect provider of choice that has additional profile fields populated with data other than email address (e.g., Google or Facebook accounts), then verify if those custom user properties are correctly mapped and displayed within your Wikispace as expected by testing them out on different pages where they should appear, such as the User Profile page (`/user`).
   
By following these steps, you can successfully map additional OpenID Connect provider fields to specific XWiki user property values. Remember that this approach requires some knowledge of XML and Java programming languages along with familiarity working within a Wikispace environment like XWiki or similar open-source wiki software solutions such as Confluence Enterprise Edition (CE) from Atlassian Corporation Pty Ltd, which also supports OIDC authentication.

#-#

#-# It's possible to associate non standard properties coming from the OpenID Connect provider with the XWiki user.  
#-# It's a map with the name of the XWiki user property and a format similar to the one defined in oidc.user.nameFormater for the OpenID Connect side.  
#-#   
# oidc.user.mapping=myxproperty1=${oidc.user.subject}  
# oidc.user.mapping=myxproperty2=myprefix-${oidc.user.subject}  
  
#-# The righs each new user should have on its own profile as a comma (only comma, no white space allowed) separated list. Setting a right also implies that all the others users don't have it.  
#-# For example if you want that only users have view right on their profile but thay can modify their own profile you could use:  
# oidc.user.oidc.user.ownProfileRights=view,edit  
#-#

#-# \* profile: Requests that access to the end-user's default profile claims at the UserInfo endpoint be granted by the issued access token.  
#-# \* email: Requests that access to the email and email\_verified claims at the UserInfo endpoint be granted by the issued access token.  
#-# \* address: Requests that access to address claim at the UserInfo endpoint be granted by the issued access token.  
#-# \* phone: Requests that access to the {phone\_number and phone\_number\_verified claims at the UserInfo endpoint be granted by the issued access token.  
#-# \* offline\_access: Requests that an OAuth 2.0 refresh token be issued that can be used to obtain an access token that grants access the end-user's UserInfo endpoint even when the user is not present (not logged in).  
#-#   
#-# But depending on the provider more can be listed.  
#-#   
#-# The default is:  
# oidc.scope=openid,profile,email,address,phone  
  
#-# The response type to control the flow used by the OpenId Connect protocol.  
#-# This is often used to control if the information about the user should  
#-# be gathered from the userinfo endpoint with a request from XWiki to the provider ("code", the default)  
#-# or the id token directly provided when the provider redirects to XWiki ("id\_token")  
#-# but it's also possible to combine.  
#-# See https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1\_0.html#rfc.section.3 for mode details.  
#-# For an hybrid flow, use list syntax (so comma or several set) instead of the white space  
#-# documented in the specification to separate words.  
#-#  
#-# The default is:  
# oidc.responseType=code  
  
#-# The method used to access the userinfo endpoint.  
#-#   
#-# Supported values are:  
#-# \* GET: use GET HTTP method  
#-# \* POST: use POST HTTP method  
#-#   
#-# The default is:  
# oidc.endpoint.userinfo.method=GET  
  
#-# The pattern to use to generate the XWiki user name.  
#-#

#-# The authentication management class.  
xwiki.authentication.authclass=org.xwiki.contrib.oidc.auth.OIDCAuthServiceImpl### xwiki.properties

#-# The base URL of the OpenId Connect Provider to use as starting point to discover the provider configuration.  
#-# See following endpoints properties if the provider is does not support OpenID Connect discovery.  
#-# If not indicated and not custom endpoint is provided, it will be asked to the user.

# Group synchronization

The default group synchronization is enabled by adding the claim xwiki\_groups to the property oidc.userinfoclaims in the xwiki.properties file.

By default this synchronization expect to receive the list of group names (without the `wiki:XWiki.` prefix) in which the user should be placed (groups are automatically created when they don't exist). You can also define a mapping between the XWiki groups and the provider groups using oidc.groups.mapping property.

It's also possible to implement your own custom group synchronization in a listener. See [Listeners section](https://extensions.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Extension/OpenID%20Connect/OpenID%20Connect%20Authenticator/#HListeners).

# Customization

## Templates

The authenticator uses a template to ask the user for the target provider when it's not provided in the configuration. This template can be overwritten through the standard [template system](https://extensions.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Extension/Template%20Module).

The name of the template is oidc/client/provider.vm.

## Listeners

It's possible to implement an event [listener](https://extensions.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Extension/Observation%20Module%20Local) and be notified during user profile update to add more to this process or do other things after it:

* org.xwiki.contrib.oidc.event.OIDCUserUpdating to modify the user profile before it being saved
* org.xwiki.contrib.oidc.event.OIDCUserUpdated to do something after the user profile has been saved

# Troubleshooting

## Enable DEBUG log

See [Logging Admin Guide](https://xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/AdminGuide/Logging).

The specific packages to track for OpenID Connect module is org.xwiki.contrib.oidc. There is several ways to enable debug log.

# oidc.skipped=false## In-wiki configuration

XWiki 1.30+ The OIDC authenticator can be configured in XWiki, and to rely on multiple configurations which get selected through a user cookie.

In order to use the in-wiki configuration of the OIDC authenticator, you will still need to define the configuration key xwiki.authentication.authclass in xwiki.cfg. Once the OIDC Authenticator installed, you will be able to define new OIDC Client configurations through objects of class XWiki.OIDC.ClientConfigurationClass.

The property "Configuration name" of the object will define the name of the OIDC configuration being declared. Use default for the default OIDC configuration. The other properties are similar to the properties defined in xwiki.properties. Use the key oidc.defaultClientConfiguration in xwiki.properties to change the name of the OIDC configuration that should be used by default.

When creating multiple in-wiki configurations, each configuration will be selectable by the user through the cookie oidcProvider. You can change the name of this cookie with the key oidc.clientConfigurationCookie in xwiki.properties.
